ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Junk DNA and a recent biological study result...
ygData.msgSnippet: Interesting article...thanks for the link, Jim. But I think the researcher overlooks a possible explanation for junk DNA, the one we re discussing on the list.

Interesting article...thanks for the link, Jim.

But I think the researcher overlooks a possible explanation for junk
DNA, the one we're discussing on the list.

<blockquote>
Another possibility, as Rubin acknowledges, is that these regions
serve a purpose too subtle to be seen in the tests done on mice.
  
"It may say as much about our inability to detect any phenotypes as it
says about the function of this region," says David Haussler of the
University of California, Santa Cruz, who thinks the work of Rubin's
team is impressive and significant. "My sense is they do have confer
some kind of advantage."

There might be a third explanation: similar regions on other
chromosomes could make up for the deletions. "It could be that these
elements are so critical that there is redundancy in the system," says
Kelly Frazer of Perlegen Sciences in California.
</blockquote>

They're looking for explanations based on organism-level fitness. 

The primary explanations they're overlooking is:

That junk DNA serves *no* adaptive purpose to the individual mouse. 
The gene-centric view of evolution, or selfish gene concept, proposes
that organisms are just a gene's way of making more genes.  Genes
exist to persist.  Junk DNA could essentially be parasitic (or at
least commensal), persisting only to serve itself.

It could also be that, as we've been discussing on this list,
populations do better if their individuals have a "toolbox" of old
genes with which to experiment building new phenotypes, so that the
source of new traits isn't always novel mutations, but the
exploitation of old traits that lay dormant in junk DNA.  But this
explanation requires a population-based view of selection, which I
don't think is very widely held.

Derek


On Thu, 3 Jun 2004 09:49:40 -0700 (PDT), Jim O'Flaherty, Jr.
<jim_oflaherty_jr@...> wrote:
> 
> Derek,
> 
> I thought you might like this article at New Scientist:

> 
> I think this is pretty relevant to the "junk DNA" discussion in biology.
> 
> A relevant quote:
> "He thinks it is pretty clear that these [DNA] sequences have no major role in growth and
> development. "There has been a circular argument that if it's [DNA] conserved it has activity.""
>
